bibl.title: Notes on Reed's laboratory notebook, New York Academy of Medicine, [19--]

div1.p: Notes describe the New York Academy of Medicine's acquisition of Walter Reed's notebook on the yellow fever experiments. [The notebook had somehow come into the possession of Reed's former laboratory assistant, John S. Neate.]

div1.head: Notes on Reed's laboratory notebook, New York Academy of Medicine, [19--]
div1.p:
“In November, 1931, Dr. - -, an interne at the - Hospital,
told Dr. - that he had Walter Reed's notebook of cases of yellow
fever. Before Dr. - brought the book to me, I heard, third-handed,
that when he was working as a medical student one summer at the Army
Medical Library, he had rescued the book from an ash barrel. He told
me, however, that this notebook was amongst the things at the
Medical School which had been sent by the Medical Department of the
Army, and that he had recovered it as it was being thrown out. One of
his instructors had said he might have it. I felt that the proper
home for the MS. was at the Army Medical Library or the Walter Reed
Medical Centre. Dr. - had tried without success, he said, to com-
municate by telephone with the authorities at the latter place. He
asked several thousand dollars, but on advice of the Library Committee,
I offered twenty-five with permission to go up to fifty. The book was
in my safe for some time, then taken away by Dr. - . Towards the end
of April, 1932, he telephoned, saying he would take what I had offered,
namely, twenty-five dollars. It is the laboratory book of Dr. Walter
Reed, and besides other notes, gives the urine findings of the group of
men who voluntarily submitted to inoculation with yellow fever.”

General F. F. Russell came to see me on or about 12 January 1933,
and said that part of the book was certainly in Sergeant Neate's hand.
Neate was a technician to Reed. Later Neate took an M.D. and was a
competent pathologist.

A short time later General Russell's secretary sent the following
to be used in wording a label for the notebook:

"Walter Reed and Laboratory Notebook
"Dr. Russell says a good way to label the book is
"Record of the Yellow Fever Commission's Work in
the handwriting of Dr. Neate
"Dr. Neate was laboratory assistant to Dr. Reed
and the book is a record of the Commission's work in
Havana.
“Dr. Russell says when the laboratory was broken
up some employee in the building probably got hold of
it and had the idea of selling it.”
